description: From Middle French confronter, from Old French confronter, from Medieval Latin confrontāre, from con- + frons (“forehead”, “front”).

verbs.description: confront (third-person singular simple present confronts, present participle confronting, simple past and past participle confronted)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To stand or meet facing, especially in competition, hostility or defiance; to come face to face with
examples: It is important that police officers learn to deescalate situations in which someone confronts them aggressively.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To bring someone face to face with something.
examples: We should confront him about the missing money.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To come up against; to encounter.
examples: Inter Milan are to confront Juventus in the final.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To set a thing side by side with; to compare.
(transitive) To put a thing facing to; to set in contrast to.
